name: Causal Inference and ML (Imbens)
description: Guido Imbens' Nobel lectures. Matrix completion for synthetic controls, the rigorous foundation for tech metrics.
summary: Nobel laureate Guido Imbens presents foundational lectures on causal inference methods, with emphasis on matrix completion techniques for synthetic control methods. These rigorous econometric foundations are essential for modern tech metrics and experimental design. The lectures bridge traditional econometrics with machine learning approaches to causal questions.
use_cases: Evaluating impact of product launches using synthetic control methods
Building rigorous A/B testing frameworks with proper causal identification

name: Double ML (Chernozhukov)
description: Belloni & Chernozhukov on Post-Double Selection Lasso. Use ML as controls while getting valid p-values.
summary: Double Machine Learning is a method that combines machine learning predictions with causal inference to estimate treatment effects while maintaining valid statistical inference. It uses cross-fitting and sample splitting to remove bias from regularized models like Lasso when estimating causal parameters. The approach allows economists to leverage high-dimensional controls without sacrificing the ability to conduct valid hypothesis tests.
use_cases: Estimating treatment effects in high-dimensional observational data with many potential confounders
Running A/B tests with machine learning-based propensity score matching while preserving statistical validity
synthetic_questions: how to use ML for treatment effects with valid p-values
combining machine learning with econometric inference

The book serves as both a graduate-level reference and a bridge between theory and application in econometric analysis.

description: Chetan Sharma (Eppo founder) discusses platform architecture and modern data stack integration for experimentation. Deep dive into building experimentation infrastructure.

name: MIT IDE YouTube Channel
description: CODE@MIT conference talks on digital experimentation. Features leading researchers and practitioners discussing cutting-edge experimentation methods.

name: Stanford ML + Causal Inference Course
description: 19 lectures combining machine learning with causal inference. Comprehensive academic treatment of modern causal ML methods from Stanford GSB.

name: Peter Frazier: Signaling with Surge Pricing (Simons 2018)
description: Natural experiment from surge heatmap outage proving 10-60% of driver repositioning comes from surge visibility. Foundational work on information design in marketplaces.

name: Jonathan Hall: Reflections of an Economist Who Manages People (Stanford 2024)
description: Uber's Chief Economist on transitioning from research to leadership. Bay Area Tech Economics Seminar at Stanford.

name: New Books in Economics: Discovering Prices (Paul Milgrom)
description: Inside the FCC's $7 billion spectrum auction design. Nobel laureate explains how auction theory became real-world policy.

name: a16z Podcast: The Marketplace Rules
description: Jeff Jordan (former OpenTable CEO) on trust management and community dynamics in marketplaces. Essential for marketplace builders.

name: Acquired: The Uber IPO
description: Multi-hour unit economics analysis; surge pricing evolution. Deep-dive into Uber's business model and marketplace dynamics.

name: Acquired: Airbnb
description: Payment structure innovation; platform-favorable cashflow. How Airbnb built a marketplace that works financially.

name: a16z Podcast: Pricing, Pricing, Pricing
description: Martin Casado and Mark Cranney on why pricing is 'the single decision that impacts valuation most'. Practical pricing strategy for startups.

name: The Mixtape: Chris Nosko Interview
description: Uber VP on transitioning from academia to industry; two-sided matching through prices. Scott Cunningham's podcast with the academic-turned-practitioner.

name: NFX Podcast: Scott Cook on Network Effects
description: Intuit founder on how network effects saved eBay from Bezos; common two-sided marketplace mistakes. Lessons from a legendary entrepreneur.

name: Lenny's Podcast: Ramesh Johari on Marketplace Lessons
description: Stanford professor and advisor to Uber, Airbnb, Bumble, Stripe. Marketplace lessons from advising the biggest platforms.
